question: Question_A_16
sols:
The first plane

\begin{align*}\displaystyle{}y-z=1\end{align*}

has normal \textbf{n$_1$}={[}0,1,-1{]} (just the coefficients on x,y,z).
The second plane

\begin{align*}\displaystyle{}2x+y+z=2\end{align*}

has normal \textbf{n$_2$}={[}2,1,1{]}. Let's call the direction our line
has \textbf{v}. Notice that since \textbf{v} is an intersection of the
two planes then by definition it is on plane 1 and plane 2. Therefore

\begin{align*}\mathbf{n}_1\times\mathbf{v}=\mathbf{0} \quad\text{and}\quad \mathbf{n}_2\times\mathbf{v}=\mathbf{0}.\end{align*}

Therefore we seek \textbf{v} so that it is orthogonal to both normal
vectors. The cross product, by definition, provides this direction.
Therefore,

\begin{align*}\mathbf{v}=\mathbf{n}_1\times\mathbf{n}_2=[0,1,-1]\times[2,1,1]=[2,-2,-2].\end{align*}

We want this to have length 1 and so we see that

\begin{align*}|\mathbf{v}|=\sqrt{12}=2\sqrt{3}.\end{align*} Therefore we get that the unit
norm vector, $\mathbf{\hat{v}}$ is

\begin{align*}\mathbf{\hat{v}}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}}[1,-1,-1].\end{align*}
hints:
The line is an intersection of two planes and so by definition it is on
both planes. What is the relationship to any point on a plane and its
normal?

As an alternative method, how can we re-write this problem as a matrix
problem?
